questions.text: In 2018, an oncology outpatient department of a tertiary care hospital documented 180 breast cancer diagnoses. All diagnosed patients immediately commenced treatment. Upon reevaluation five years later, it was determined that 32 of the initially diagnosed patients had succumbed to the disease. Based on this information, calculate the 5-year survival rate for breast cancer patients treated at this hospital.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 82.2%

 

The question is asking about the survival rate of the patients with breast cancer.

 

 

No. of patients diagnosed with breast cancer are 180.

 

No. of patients died are 32, but to calculate the survival rate, we need to know how many survived. So, the number of patients who survived after treatment are 180-32 = 148.

 

Putting the values, we get (148/180) x100 = 82.2%

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-year survival rate –

 

  • Is used as ‘an index of success in cancer treatment’
  • Is not an appropriate measure to assess therapy that was introduced less than 5 years ago
  • WHENEVER screening is performed: Higher 5-year survival rate is observed; THIS IS A POTENTIAL BIAS DUE TO earlier diagnosis being made (and not because people live longer)

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 66.

questions.text: In the realm of public health and policy making, it is crucial to assess the impact of diseases not just in terms of mortality, but also in terms of the disability and reduced quality of life they cause. The policymakers in a certain region are focusing their efforts on interventions aimed at reducing premature disability caused by various health conditions. Which of the following indices would be the most appropriate and helpful for them to make informed decisions on where to allocate resources and which interventions to prioritize?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Disability-adjusted life-years

 

Option C.

 

The Disability-Adjusted Life Year (DALY) quantifies the burden of disease from mortality and morbidity. It's a measure that combines in one metric the time lived with disability and the time lost due to premature mortality. 

 

  • Years of Life Lost (YLL) = No of deaths × Expected remaining years of life (As per Global standard life expectancy – Japan)
  • Years Lost to Disability (YLD) = No of incident cases injury/illness × Average duration of disease × Weighting factor (0 Perfect health to 1 Death)
  • DALY = YLL + YLD

 

Educational Objective:

 

DALYs can measure ‘both mortality and disability together’

 

Case fatality rate measures ‘virulence of an organism’ or ‘killing power of a disease’

 

Dependency ratio measures the ‘need for society to provide for its’ younger and older groups’

 

Morbidity data measures ‘any departure from health’

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 26.

questions.text: A Public Health Consultant is evaluating the incidence of tuberculosis (TB) in a district with a population of 1,92,800. On January 1, 2021, there were 45 existing cases of TB. Throughout the year, an additional 32 new cases were reported. Calculate the incidence of TB in the district for the year 2021.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 16.5 cases per lakh population

 

Option A.

 

 

No. of new cases of TB in 2021 was 32.

 

Population at risk is = 192800 - 45 = 1,92,755

 

Putting the values, we get – (32/1,92,755) x1000 = 16.6 cases per lac population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Incidence: Is defined as the ‘no. of new cases’ occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time. Incidence is a RATE, expressed per 1000

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 68.

choices.text: The crude all-cause mortality rate is greater in men
The case-fatality from this disease is greater in women
The duration of this disease is shorter in men
Risk factors for the disease are more common in women

questions.text: A researcher is evaluating a dataset on a specific disease in a population and observes a perplexing trend. Although women in this population are being diagnosed with the disease at a rate five times higher than men, the prevalence of the disease appears to be the same for both genders. Given these circumstances, what is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The case-fatality from this disease is greater in women

 

Option B:

 

Higher incidence of a disease in a specified population means number of new cases are higher in that population than the other. Prevalence means number of new cases plus old cases. So if in females, incidence is five times higher, it means number of new cases is higher. So, according to the question, in order to keep prevalence same in both male and female, if new cases are rising, it means old cases must decrease, which can also be said as – Case fatality from this disease is greater in women.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The crude all-cause mortality rate is greater in men: It’s a false statement. If mortality is higher in men, prevalence would be much lower in men. But the question mentions that the prevalence of the disease in both male and female is equal.

 

Option C. The duration of this disease is shorter in men: If the disease is of shorter duration, prevalence would decrease as compared to that in female.

 

Option D. Risk factors for the disease are more common in women: While more common risk factors in women could explain the higher diagnosis rate, it does not explain why the prevalence is the same in both genders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence: 


                Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of the disease


                P = I × d

 

  • Incidence reflects causal factors
  • Duration reflects the prognostic factors

 

Ref: Leon gordis, 5th ed, pg 86

Coal workers has less mortality compared to whole population
Mortality is more in coal workers compared to whole population
Cannot be determined with above data

questions.text: A researcher conducted a study to analyze the mortality rates of coal workers. The standard mortality ratio (SMR) for the coal workers was found to be 112. Based on this information, how does the mortality rate of coal workers compare to the general population?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mortality is more in coal workers compared to whole population

 

Option C:

 

 

 

 

 

If the ratio had value greater than 100, then the occupation would appear to carry a greater mortality risk than that of the whole population. If the ratio had value less than 100, then the occupation risks of mortality would seem to be proportionately less than that for the whole population.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Standard mortality ratio (SMR) is used to compare mortality rates between a study population and the general population. An SMR above 100 indicates higher mortality in the study population, an SMR below 100 indicates lower mortality, and an SMR of 100 indicates equal mortality rates.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 68.

choices.text: 2 per 100 PY
20 per 100 PY
3 per 100 PY
30 per 100 PY

questions.text:
A study on ischemic heart disease (IHD) commenced in January 1991 and concluded in December 2000. Initially, 5 subjects were enrolled, with an additional 5 joining at different times during the study. By the end of 2000, 2 individuals had developed IHD. Given the follow-up details provided below, what is the incidence rate of IHD in this study?

 

 

Legend: > = Follow up starts; O = Follow up ends, subject remains without IHD; A = Subject died due to some other disease; ? = Subject was lost to follow up; X = Subject developed IHD
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 per 100 PY

 

Option C.

 

Incidence rate is also known as ‘Incidence density'

 

Calculate the total person-years (PY) of follow-up for each subject:

 

  • Subject 1: 1991-2000 (10 years)
  • Subject 2: 1991-2000 (10 years)
  • Subject 3: 1991-1995 (5 years)
  • Subject 4: 1991-1998 (8 years)
  • Subject 5: 1991-1992 (1 year)
  • Subject 6: 1992-2000 (9 years)
  • Subject 7: 1993-1998 (6 years)
  • Subject 8: 1995-2000 (6 years)
  • Subject 9: 1995-1998 (4 years)
  • Subject 10: 1997-2000 (4 years)

 

Total duration of observation= 63 person years

 

Incidence density/rate = 2/63 = 0.03 PY = 3 per 100 person years

 

Educational Objective:

 

Incidence: Is defined as the ‘no. of new cases’ occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time. Incidence is a RATE, expressed per 1000

 

 

Incidence is the best measure of disease frequency in etiological studies

 

Incidence can be determined from: Cohort study

 

Ref: Park 27/e p69

questions.text: In District X with mid-year population of 1,20,000, during 2022, total of 2400 deaths were reported, among them 40 deaths out of 5000 cases were due to pneumonia. based on this information, calculate the case fatality rate of pneumonia in District X for 2022?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.8%

 

Option A:

 

Case Fatality Rate Calculation -

 

 

Number of deaths due to pneumonia are 40. Number of pneumonia cases are 5000.

 

So putting the values directly into the formula – we get (40/5000) x100 = 0.8%

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case Fatality Rate - 

 

  • CFR represents ‘killing power of a disease’
  • It is ‘closely related to virulence of organism
  • CFR = Total no. of deaths due to a disease/Total no. of cases due to a disease × 100
  • CFR is a Proportion: Always expressed in percentage
  • CFR is the ‘complement of Survival Rate’, thus CFR = 1 – Survival Rate

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 66.

questions.text: Analyze mortality data from a city with a total population of 1,44,000 during the year 2022. In that year, there were 3200 reported deaths, and out of those, 285 were due to road traffic accidents. Based on this information, calculate the proportionate mortality rate for road traffic accidents in this city for the year 2022.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 8.9%

 

Option B:

 

Proportional mortality rate means how many deaths of the total that are occurring at a geographic location in a given time, is due to a particular disease. It can be written as -

 

 

 No. of deaths from the RTA = 285

 

Total no. of deaths = 3200

 

Putting the values, we get (285/3200) x100 = 8.9%

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proportional mortality rate - PMR is number of deaths due to a particular cause (or in a specific age group) per 100 (or 1000) total deaths. PMR Is the ‘simplest measure of estimating the burden of a disease’. 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 66.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing different epidemiological measures to understand disease occurrence in a population. She needs to identify a measure where the numerator is not a part of the denominator. Which of the following measures fits this description?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ratio
 

Option B:

 

Ratio - expresses a relation in size between two random quantities. The numerator is not a component of the denominator. The numerator and denominator may involve an interval of time or may be instantaneous in time. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rate: A rate measures the occurrence of some particular event in a defined population during a given time-period. A rate comprises the following elements - numerator, denominator, time specification, and multiplier. 

 

Option C. Percentage: Numerator is a part of denominator in percentage

 

Option D. Proportion: A proportion is a ratio that indicates the relation in magnitude of a part of the whole. The numerator is always included in the denominator. A proportion is usually expressed as a percentage. Ex. Prevalence and Case fatality rate

 

Educational Objective:

 

Incidence is a rate; Prevalence is a proportion. 

 

Ratio is an epidemiological measure where the numerator is not part of the denominator. It compares two distinct entities.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 63.

choices.text: Determine the actual number of deaths that occurred in specific age groups in a population
Correct death rates for missing age information
Compare deaths in persons of the same age group
Eliminate the effects of differences in the age distributions of populations in comparing death rates

questions.text: In epidemiology, there are various methods used to compare mortality data between different populations or over different time periods. One of these methods includes age-adjusted death rates. What is the primary purpose of utilizing age-adjusted death rates?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Eliminate the effects of differences in the age distributions of populations in comparing death rates

 

Option D.

 

Standardized rates remove the confounding effect of different age structures and yield a single standardized or adjusted rate, by which the mortality experience can be compared directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Standardization for the characteristic(s) responsible for the differences in comparison is necessary

 

Age and sex are two of the most common variables used for standardization and they are called Standardized rates

 

Ref: Leon gordis, 5th ed, pg 85

choices.text: The incidence of infection is 251,880 per year
The prevalence of infection is 251,880 per year
The mortality rate is 24.2 per 1,000 person
The 1-year cumulative incidence is 24.2 per 1,000 persons

questions.text: A novel virus has recently been identified in a country with a population of 10.4 million residents. In the year following its introduction, a total of 251,880 people were reported to have been infected by the virus. The infection is noted to have a low mortality rate. As a public health professional, you are required to determine the correct epidemiological measure to describe the extent of the disease spread in the first year. Which of the following is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. The 1-year cumulative incidence is 24.2 per 1,000 persons

 

Option D.

 

1-year Cumulative incidence means total number of newly infected people in the population at risk in one year.

 

 

No. of infected people – 251880

 

Total population at risk – 10,400,000

 

Cumulative incidence = (251880/10400000) x 1000 = 24.2

 

Educational Objective:

 

Incidence: Is defined as the ‘no. of new cases’ occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time

 

Ref: Leon gordis, 5th ed, pg 64

questions.text: In a town having a population of 200,000 at midyear, 2,200 individuals were reported to have diabetes mellitus on January 1, 2022. Throughout that year, 450 new cases were diagnosed, and 75 individuals with diabetes mellitus passed away due to complications. Based on this information, calculate the point prevalence of diabetes mellitus in the town as of December 31, 2022.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 12.87 per 1000

 

Option B:

 

 Point prevalence of a disease is defined as the number of all current cases (old and new) of a disease at one point in time, in relation to a defined population.

 

Point prevalence (in percentage) is given by the formula:

 

                                        

 

 

Point prevalence of diabetes mellitus on 31.12.2022

 

= {(2200-75) + 450} x 100 /(200000-75)

 

= 2575 x 100/ 199925

 

= 1.287 per 100

 

But, the options are in per 1000 population, so the answer is 12.87/1000 population

 

Educational Objective:

 

Point Prevalence is defined as Number of total cases at a given point of time


Period prevalence is defined by Number of total cases in a given year
